div1.head: Jim to Mlle. Marcelle Guerin June 23rd 1915
div1.p: Now, isn’t that just like it? Would only happen once in a thousand times, but the letter and the postal came together. Our Marichal des logis went to headquarters today and happened to get both pieces of mail. Still until proved otherwise I think S.S. Americaine Y is better than the Secteur Postal 8H Convoy. The officers around here seem to think so.

I haven’t heard from Paul in a long time; don’t know about his flaws, and as for the wedding that’s in the uncertain future. Hope it comes off soon, and that I can get a leave, for I most certainly am anxious to see you. Heavens it will be great to talk to you again and look you over. I always got a lot of pleasure out of looking you over, you know — or possibly you didn’t. The directions as to how to reach you are very correct I presume but as far as I understand them I go to the Etoile, walk around six times, start down for a tram, get off and walk over to the Trocaders [sp?] and turn to my left, then walk back and turn to my right and end by going out to Neuilly. Oh of course I’ll get there all right. That’s one sure thing. What I am worrying about now is whether I’ll get in before the war’s over.

We are honored today by a call from Captain Watts the Australian aviator in the French Army and Lieu. Noel the famous flier. Watts is a wonderful looking fellow. He’s stationed right down the road towards Toul, some twenty kilometers away, and from that aviation ground starts for his work over the trenches. We can tell him by the fact that he flies low and we watch the Germans firing at him. Firing at aeros is a foolish occupation. Only about once in five thousand times do shots come anywheres [sic]near them.

I told you in my last letter about visiting the tent squad and finding old Doty hanging around there and as for Suckley I write him off and on — just to make him jealous — and hear that he’s doing well. I suppose you know they made a general clean up at the Ambulance and the among others O’Hagan was fired for just being O’Hagan and Blair for being Blair. Poor rough old Harris, the horse fellow got it too, but I was sorry to see him go. He was all right.
The staff car, by which I shall send back this letter is two days overdue for some reason I can’t understand.

Its fortunate that we are to have the Pierce - Arrow for it will help a great deal. We are a little short of drivers. Two men have been sent back, Curtin had to return to America and two others didn’t want to stand the risk and returned to Paris. An English fellow named Bushwell, a pretty, pink cheeked chap, the scion of some ancient and honorable family is our last addition. I don’t know how he’ll make out. In some ways I’m dubious but hope he’s all right for we have trouble getting men. They put up this “Well you see I’m the only child” spiel, and go to the Vosges or Dunkirk. We’ve got an excellent crowd now, with the exception of one awful lemon whose presence I can’t understand. Yes, I miss Curtin a good deal. Its a shame he had to go. You miss him a lot too, don’t you now? D----- it!

Don’t get a false idea of our town from the inclosed, [sic] for its a photo of the worst shot up place in the collection. Worst appearing, I mean, for of course there are some houses that are all done for, nothing left, and others with no insides for the big shells fall almost straight down.

Did I tell you we are to get the work of the next section and that we
will go to Leiney and Flirey and Tey en Haye? Auberge St. Pierre near the Quart en Reserve of Le Bois le Pretre is our last point of call at present. I never wrote you, did I, about my trip up to the first line trenches; to the Col de Cygne; Le Gros Chene where the rotten dead are buried, etc? It was about a month ago. Oh, yes I did. I remember now.

My Mlle. Hostess is still kind to me. New baskets of cherries appear unexpectedly in my room, vases of roses, and now I find ruffles on the bed linen. That is really too much. I can’t figure out the idea. Modesty compells [sic] me to keep silent the fact that my room-mate —I mean suite-mate doesn’t draw the attentions. Which reminds me — how is Sergius dear?
Doesn’t the Nona McAdoo & C. Britton stuff make you tired? They should have stayed at home.

Are you really standing up under your work? I’m quite worried about you sometimes. Of course you’re strong — stronger by far than a great many — but you take things so very seriously and go at it so conscientiously that you are apt to over due [sic] yourself. I don’t know of anyone that should be admired more than you for what you are doing and the way you
are doing it. I never will forget your observation to the effect that what makes France great is “Its soil and its women” The more I see of the wonder- fully cultivated fields of France, and the more I think of you, the better I understand the truth of your statement. This coming to your country has done me a wonderful amount of good and I believe that most of it is due to the fact that I had you to point out some of the hidden things to me, some of the subtle influences obtaining here but which do not have effect unless one is open to them. Sometimes, when I think of how distressingly American you are; when I recall some of your remarks about being anxious to get back to that God forsaken New York I could ring your charmingly formed neck but then I remember that you are here helping “us French” and I forgive you.

I was on twenty four hours service at our former base, Dieulouard, yesterday evacuating to the train which runs up to the hint [sp?] of shell fire a few kilometers below. I have usually dreaded that long day which falls to each of us every ten days, but this time I enjoyed it. We had sneaked some of our friends down from an Algerian battery in Le Bois Le Pretre
so that they could rest at Dieulouard for a change, and last night they gave a concert. We sat in a little garden around a long table. It had rained during the day and cleaned the air, so that the light of the full moon was brilliant and glorious. They sang weird Arab songs while we kept beat on the table, and then a foolish sort of fellow from Paris regaled us with peculiar pieces “Le Metro” where one imitates the whistles and closing of doors, etc. The crowd had gradually increased and then suddenly into our midst glided one of the fairest young women I’ve seen in a long time. She was quite young; nineteen I would say, and slim and graceful. She wore a little flower bordered apron and tiny pumps. She was quite foreign to those surroundings, it seemed, and the presence of the Arabs and rough soldiers accentuated her tenderness. An old sergeant, who stayed at her house had brought her down to hear the concert. He was either very broad or didn’t know what was coming for soon after she arrived the Arabs executed one of the wildest dances I’ve seen. They chanted, and for draperies they used large handkerchiefs while the fellow from Paris managed to get
wonderful cymbal effects out of a beer bottle with a swinging cap and a door for a sounding board. It was late when we started home. The last thing I remember was how beautiful the girl looked in the moonlight. She may be impossible in the day. I don’t know.

This letter was started three days ago and still the staff car doesn’t come. I can’t understand the delay. Maybe they are still laughing at the beer [sp?] section. The last I’ve heard about their flaws is to the effect that they contemplate moving near Mortmare to the North west of us. If such is the case I presume we’ll evacuate to some point where their cars will take the wounded we have brought them.

One of our men became very ill with pluresie [sic], or however you spell it, and was evacuated to Toul. Today he is being sent to the south of France in spite of the fact that he wants to go to Paris. He has to follow the regular route. I suppose, therefore that if I get wounded I won’t have the pleasure of going to Paris but will end up at Lyons or someplace down south.
Outside of not seeing you and Paul I don’t care tho. [sic] We would be taken care of well and treated as officers, as Ferguson, who is being operated on at the Ambulance, however, for up here where instruments are lacking and what they have are dull one’s chances are slim. Night before last out of eleven cases where an operation was performed eleven died. One died in my car before I could get him to the ambulance or their would have been twelve. So many poor fellows die in hospitals; cars, postes de secours, etc, and there is no way of letting their families know just how they died. That seems a pity for people seem to be anxious to learn about the last minutes of their own. The fellow I had began yelling about his mother, and lifting up his head, and cigarettes, all at the same time as I locked him in. When we reached Bleuod he ceased to make a noise and must have died then. The other two in with him were so far gone themselves they couldn’t have minded it much.
